newsitem.title: USA: Most Americans back Clinton on Iraq attack - poll.
newsitem.headline: Most Americans back Clinton on Iraq attack - poll.

text.p: Americans overwhelmingly approve of President Bill Clinton's missile attack on Iraq, an ABC News poll shows.
However, the poll, released late on Tuesday, indicated most Americans do not think the attack will stop Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein from further violating terms of the Gulf War ceasefire.
Seventy-nine percent of Americans said they approved of the U.S. attack on Iraq early on Tuesday, and 16 percent disapproved.
Five percent had no opinion. The poll was completed before Tuesday night's second wave of U.S. military action against Iraq.
Fifty-four percent of Americans polled said the United States' overall policy on Iraq was about right, but 39 percent said it was too weak.
However, 74 percent said the missile attack would not keep Iraq from violating the terms of the Gulf War ceasefire. Twenty-one percent said it would.
Fifty-two percent said the United States was headed for a another war with Iraq, against 44 percent who said it was not.
The poll involved 515 adults interviewed by telephone on Tuesday. The margin of error is 5 percent.
